pretext: Now that you’ve learned vowels, as well as the consonant-vowel combinations of “K” and “S”, let’s proceed to “T”.

prompt: “Ta” is written as “た”. The character itself already looks like the word “Ta” which makes it a lot easier to remember.

“Chi,” which technically doesn’t have a “T,” is grouped in with the consonant-vowel combinations “T”. Similar to “S” where there is no “Si” sound, “T” has no “Ti” sound. “Chi” is written as “ち”. It looks like the number “5”.

Unlike the other hiragana letters, “tsu” is its own sound. Its sound is similar to that of blowing on the opening of a bottle. It is represented by the character “つ,” which looks like the tip of a shoe.
“Te” is written as “て”. The word “Te” also means “Hand” in Japanese. If you look at the palm of your hand, you’ll see that the creases resemble the character of “Te”.
“To” is represented by the character “と”. It looks like the letter “Y” if it was getting ready to jump. You can also think of a TOad to remember the character.
Those were the “T” consonant and vowel combinations in hiragana. To recap:
Let’s learn a couple of words using the consonant-vowels of “T”. Remember, you don’t have to memorize the meaning of these words. This is just so you can recognize the characters being used.
“Tsuchi” means “Soil” and is written as “つち”.
